facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 193 and 194 of 1971 filed by State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No, 193 194 of 1971. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated April 11, 1969 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 1416 and 2918 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 11, 1969 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Writ Petitions Nos. 1416 and 2918 of 1967.

facts.text: Mysore High Court quashed State Government Notifications Nos. GSRS. 384, 392 and 303 dated 30th August, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore had quashed three State Government Notifications Nos. GSRS. 384, and 392 and 303, dated 30th August, 1967, amending the Mysore State Accounts Services  Recruitment  Rules, 1959,

facts.text: Notifications amended Mysore State Accounts Services Recruitment Rules, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: amending the Mysore State Accounts Services  Recruitment  Rules, 1959, and the promotions of Respondents 3 to 8 of in Writ Petition No. 1416/67.

facts.text: High Court quashed promotions of Respondents 3 to 8 in Writ Petition No. 1416/67.

anchor.surface_text: , amending the Mysore State Accounts Services  Recruitment  Rules, 1959, and the promotions of Respondents 3 to 8 of in Writ Petition No. 1416/67.

facts.text: High Court directed State of Mysore to consider cases of petitioners with Respondents 3 to 8 for promotion under 1959 Rules notified on 26-5-1959.

anchor.surface_text: It had directed the State of Mysore to companysider the cases of the petitioners with those of Respondents 3 to 8 for promotion before it under the Mysore State Accounts Services  Recruitment  Rules 1959, made under Article 309 of the Constitution of India. numberified on 26-5-1959.

facts.text: Petitioners joined Accounts services in Comptroller's office of former Mysore State as first and second Division Clerks.

anchor.surface_text: The two petitioners before the High Court, who are respon- dents before us, had joined the Accounts services in the Comptrollers office of the former Mysore State as first and second Division Clerks.

facts.text: After abolition of Comptroller's office, petitioners worked as Accounts Clerks under Chief Engineer, P.W.D.

anchor.surface_text: Consequent upon the abolition of the Comptrollers office the petitioners began working as Accounts Clerks under the Chief Engineer, P.W.D.

facts.text: On 31st October, 1953, Divisional Accounts Cadre in scale Rs. 130-335 created by Mysore Government under Chief Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: On 31st October, 1953, a Divisional Accounts Cadre, in the scale of Rs. 130-335 was created by the Mysore Government under the administrative companytrol of the Chief Engineer.

facts.text: Petitioners passed prescribed examinations and absorbed in Divisional Accounts Cadre.

anchor.surface_text: Both the petitioners passed the prescribed examinations and were absorbed in the Divisional Accounts Cadre.

facts.text: In April 1959, P.W.D. Reorganisation Committee recommended transfer of P.W.D. Accounts Branch to Controller of State Accounts.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in April, 1959, the P.W.D. Reorganisation Committee had recommended the transfer of the P.W.D. Accounts Branch in toto to the newly set up Controller of State Accounts.

facts.text: Petitioners came under administrative control of Controller, designation changed to Accounts Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: in accordance with this recommendation, the petitioners came under the administrative companytrol of the Controller and the designation of their office was changed to that of Accounts Superintendent.

facts.text: On 15th May, 1959, P.W.D. Accounts unit and Local Fund Audit unit came under common administrative control of Controller of State Accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th May, 1959, the two formerly separate units of the Accounts service, namely the W.D. Accounts unit, under the Chief Engineer of P.W.D., and the. Local Fund Audit unit,

facts.text: On 26th May, 1959, Mysore State Accounts Services Cadre and Recruitment Rules issued and combined cadre strength fixed.

anchor.surface_text: On 26h May, 1959, the Mysore State Accounts Services Cadre and Recruitment Rules were issued and companybined cadre strength were fixed.

facts.text: High Court found clear and complete integration between the two units under 1959 Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after examining the rules of 1959, in the companytext of all the orders, proceeding and following the promulgation of these Rules, companycluded There cannot be the slightest doubt from these rules that a clear and companyplete integration was brought about between the two units.

facts.text: Qualifications and status of officers from formerly separate units were identical.

anchor.surface_text: It pointed out that the qualifications and status of the officers of the formerly separate units were identical, their work was of the same nature, the recruiting authorities were the same,

facts.text: High Court held petitioners discriminated in promotions because they worked in P.W.D. Accounts Unit.

anchor.surface_text: After examining the cases of the petitioners that, in the matter of promotions, they were discriminated against simply because they had worked in the P.W.D. Accounts Unit, which had ceased to exist,

facts.text: Figures showed striking disparity in promotional opportunities between officers of two wings.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court held that the petitioners grievances were justified. It found that figures showing the number of appointments of members of the same service derived. from the formerly separate units indicated a striking disparity in the promotional oppor- tunities between the officers of the two wings in the same cadres.

facts.text: Notifications reduced promotional posts for Public Works Accounts Unit compared to other wing.

anchor.surface_text: It said While the rules of 1959 integrated the two wings into one service and provided for promotion on the basis of seniority-cum-merit, the impugned Notifications fixing up the cadre strength reduce the number of promotional posts available to the Public Works Accounts Unit to a very low figure as companypared with the promotional opportunities open to the officers in the other wing.

facts.text: High Court struck down notifications as violations of Articles 14 and 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: It had, therefore, struck down the impugned Notifications as violations of the Constitutional guarantees given by Article 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: State contended petitioners never promoted under 1959 rules.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the State of Mysore has companytended firsly, that the petitioners, number respondents before us, were never promoted or appointed to offices held by them under the rules of 1959 so that they companyld number companyplain of denial of equality of promotional chances

facts.text: State contended 1967 amendments retrospective and legal.

anchor.surface_text: and, secondly, that the amendments made retrospectively in the rules in 1967, justifying the differences of promotional chances between the two wings of the same service, were perfectly legal and bore a rational nexus to the object of the differences made.

facts.text: Supreme Court refused to entertain State's first contention as new point not raised in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first companytention is companycerned, we are unable to entertain it for the first time in this Court. We do number find any indication that the point, even if such a position was taken on behalf of the State, was argued at all before the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court on validity of division into two classes for promotions.

anchor.surface_text: The question which remains for companysideration by us is the one relating to the validity of a division into two classes of ,members of the same service, belonging to the same cadres, for purposes of a difference to be made in their promotional chances.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the Mysore High Court rightly held that the impugned numberifications were unconstitutional. Consequently, we dismiss these appeals with one set of companyts.

arguments.claim: cannot entertain first contention as new point not argued before High Court

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first contention is concerned, we are unable to entertain it for the first time in this Court. We do not find any indication that the point, even if such a position was taken on behalf of the State, was argued at all before the Mysore High Court.

arguments.claim: purported amendments to 1959 rules disintegrating integrated service are ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: We think that it had rightly declared the purported amendments in the rules of 1959, which sought to disintegrate a service which had been integrated, to be ultra vires. Such amendments made for the purpose of justifying the illegal promotions made, in the teeth of the protection conferred by Articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution of India upon Indian citizens in Government service, could not be upheld.

arguments.claim: power under Article 309 proviso cannot validate unconstitutional discrimination

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly relied on State of Mysore v. Padmanabhacharya to hold that the power of making rules relating to recruitment and conditions of service under the proviso to Article 309 could not be used to validate unconstitutional discrimination in promotional chances of Government servants who belong to the same category.

arguments.claim: cases not considered for promotion under 1959 rules on false premise of different class violates Articles 14 and 16(1)

anchor.surface_text: Articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution must be held to be violated when members of one class are not even considered for promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Other cases mentioned by the Mysore High Court i.e. State of Punjab v. Joginder Singh 1 and K. M. Bakshi v. Union of India 2 also show that inequality of opportunity of promotion, though not unconstitutional per se, must be justified on the strength of rational criteria connected to the object for which the difference is made.

arguments.qualifiers: if on facts classes really different

arguments.claim: no rational grounds to divide integrated single class into two for promotions

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary, if the facts of a particular case disclose no such rational distinction between members of what is found to be really a single class no class distinctions can be made in selecting the best.

holdings.text: Unable to entertain the first contention for the first time in this Court as it was not argued before the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first contention is concerned, we are unable to entertain it for the first time in this Court. We do not find any indication that the point, even if such a position was taken on behalf of the State, was argued at all before the Mysore High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No indication the point was argued below; well-recognised practice not to allow new points involving facts.

holdings.text: Purported amendments to 1959 rules disintegrating the integrated service are ultra vires and cannot be upheld as they justify illegal promotions in teeth of Articles 14 and 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: We think that it had rightly declared the purported amendments in the rules of 1959, which sought to disintegrate a service which had been integrated, to be ultra vires. Such amendments made for the purpose of justifying the illegal promotions made, in the teeth of the protection conferred by Articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution of India upon Indian citizens in Government service, could not be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments seek to disintegrate integrated service to justify past illegal promotions violating constitutional equality protections.

holdings.text: Power under proviso to Article 309 cannot validate unconstitutional discrimination in promotional chances of Government servants in same category.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly relied on State of Mysore v. Padmanabhacharya to hold that the power of making rules relating to recruitment and conditions of service under the proviso to Article 309 could not be used to validate unconstitutional discrimination in promotional chances of Government servants who belong to the same category.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent that Art 309 rulemaking power subordinate to constitutional guarantees against discrimination.

holdings.text: Articles 14 and 16(1) violated when members of one class are not even considered for promotion on false premise of different class.

anchor.surface_text: Articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution must be held to be violated when members of one class are not even considered for promotion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equal consideration required under merit-cum-seniority; artificial classification excluding consideration breaches equality.

holdings.text: Division into two classes of members of same integrated service for differing promotional chances invalid under Articles 14 and 16(1) absent rational grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The question which remains for consideration by us is the one relating to the validity of a division into two classes of members of the same service, belonging to the same cadres, for purposes of a difference to be made in their promotional chances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1959 rules effected complete integration; no rational distinction post-integration; distinguishes precedents like Wadhwa and Jaisinghani where no integration or rational quotas existed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the Mysore High Court rightly held that the impugned notifications were unconstitutional. Consequently, we dismiss these appeals with one set of costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court; notifications reduce promotional posts for one wing violating equality after integration and seniority-cum-merit basis.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first contention is concerned, we are unable to entertain it for the first time in this Court. We do not find any indication that the point, even if such a position was taken on behalf of the State, was argued at all before the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We think that it had rightly declared the purported amendments in the rules of 1959, which sought to disintegrate a service which had been integrated, to be ultra vires. Such amendments made for the purpose of justifying the illegal promotions made, in the teeth of the protection conferred by Articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution of India upon Indian citizens in Government service, could not be upheld.
Consequently, we dismiss these appeals with one set of companyts.

Padmanabhacharya to hold that the power of making rules relating to recruitment and conditions of service under the proviso to Article 309 could not be used to validate unconstitutional discrimination in promotional chances of Government servants who belong to the same category.
Consequently, we dismiss these appeals with one set of companyts.
